title: George Soper
text:
George Albert Soper II (2 February 1870 – 17 June 1948) was an American <a href="Waste%20management">sanitation engineer</a>. He was best known for discovering <a href="Mary%20Mallon">Mary Mallon</a>, also known as Typhoid Mary, a carrier of <a href="typhoid%20fever">typhoid fever</a> who had no symptoms.
Biography.
Soper was the son of George Albert Soper (1837 – 1869) and Georgianna Lydia Buckman (d. 1882).
He received his degree from <a href="Rensselaer%20Polytechnic%20Institute">Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute</a> in 1895 and a PhD from <a href="Columbia%20University">Columbia University</a> in 1899. He was described as 'Major, US Army', in the entry for 1907 in the <a href="New%20York%20City%20Department%20of%20Health%20and%20Mental%20Hygiene">New York City Department of Health</a> and was identified by "Centennial Newspaper" for the discovery of the carrier, Typhoid Mary. From 1923–1928 he was the managing director of the American Society for the Control of Cancer, which later changed its name to the <a href="American%20Cancer%20Society">American Cancer Society</a>, .
Mallon was tracked down by Soper and Dr. <a href="Sara%20Josephine%20Baker">Sara Josephine Baker</a>, and was arrested by Ms. Willa Carey Noble, a bacteriologist at "Research laboratories of the Public Health Department of New York City" under <a href="William%20Hallock%20Park">William Hallock Park</a>.
